name: Massimo Vega
comment info:
Immediately striking is the strong correlation between education level and work flexibility. Workers with a bachelor's degree or higher are much more likely to work hybrid or fully remotely, while workers with a high school diploma or less overwhelmingly work in person. This trend puts into light the effect of education on job type and flexibility.
Moreover, racial and age disparities in hybrid/remote work opportunities reflect broader inequities in job distribution and accessibility.

Why do workers with more education have more remote opportunities? Is this a job-type issue, a technological access issue, or a preference of employers?
How has the pandemic reshaped workforce norms? For example, will the increase in remote work stabilize or continue to grow?

In many communities, including mine, this graph reflects ongoing shifts toward hybrid or remote work in office jobs. Friends and family with college degrees have seen improved work-life balance due to remote options. However, those in service or healthcare roles still have to work in person, often facing long commutes and inflexible schedules. This highlights the need for systemic changes to address these disparities.

Work Flexibility Depends on Education: A New Divide in the Post-Pandemic World.

name: MASON from NH
location: Beech Hill School Hopinton New Hampshire
comment info: Headline: Remote Work Revolution is a Mirage.   I notice how small the number of remote workers is as a percentage of working people and I wonder why this group gets such out sized coverage of their situation in the media. of course one answer to this question suggests itself in the graph: the highly "educated" are over represented among remote workers and their lifestyles are generally over-reported.  It's amusing to think that this small group of lucky and privileged people sometimes talk about remote work as if it were a fundamental right that they will never relinquish. This is a strange way to think of a temporary policy implemented during a health crisis that came and went. But, here we are.

A statistical point.  The term correlation refers to the relationship of quantitative variables.  Here we have two categorical variables – education level and where we work.  If there is a relationship with categorical variables, we say there is an association.

What do I notice? The graph shows the type of work (in-person, hybrid, or remote) for different education levels. Most people with lower education, like high school or some college, work in-person. People with higher education tend to work more remotely or in hybrid jobs.

name: Neil Paul
comment info: Headline: Remote Work Revolution is a Mirage.   I notice how small the number of remote workers is as a percentage of working people and I wonder why this group gets such outsized coverage of their situation in the media. of course one answer to this question suggests itself in the graph: the highly "educated" are overrepresented among remote workers and their lifestyles are generally overreported.  It's amusing to think that this small group of lucky and privileged people sometimes talk about remote work as if it were a fundamental right that they will never relinquish. This is a strange way to think of a ttemporary policy implemented during a health crisis that came and went. But, here we are.

name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
Headline: "Workplace Shifts Post-Pandemic: In-Person Dominates, but Remote Remains"

What I notice from the graph is that, as we navigate the effects of the pandemic, most people are back working in person post-pandemic, with a few opting for hybrid or remote work. However, remote and hybrid work has grown, particularly among those with higher education levels. College graduates, those with bachelor’s degrees, and even more so graduate degree holders, are working remotely or in hybrid roles at higher rates than those with less education. However, overall, in-person work remains the most popular choice, regardless of education level. I wonder how much of this shift in work patterns will be sustained, and whether younger generations or those in specific fields will continue to prefer remote work in the long run. This graph relates to me and my community, as it highlights a larger societal change that many of us have experienced—navigating the new norms of working from home or in a hybrid model and overall adjusting to pandemic after-effects.

name: Terry Shea
comment info:
Key takeaway: Higher education is correlated with remote.  Somewhat because manual labor requires onsite work, but businesses have kept remote work due to increased cost savings and productivity.
But have there been other impacts?  An increased sense of isolation?  An increased divide between the blue and white collar workers that used to interact at businesses?  Young people losing opportunities to build work relationships? This analysis needs measures such as productivity, mental health, and time.  Nonetheless, this chart will drift to more in-person as companies require days in office, but we will never go back fully.  This new found work-life balance is recognized by even the most hardened CEO.  However, you can’t underestimate the impact of an office.  Interacting in-person connects us and can spark a conversation about a new offering. 
Businesses will always do what is best for the business, and determine the optimal mix.  The ability to find the best person for a job anywhere in the world and selling and delivering services without T&E have positive impacts.  Employees have some leverage in seeking hybrid roles, but that “benefit” is determined by the work force as a whole.  
The intangible impact of in-person and the benefits of remote work must be balanced and both businesses and employees will benefit equally.

Headline: “Education can lead to autonomy (at least a perceived notion of it)”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Terry Shea --

First a statistical point.  The term correlation refers to the relationship of quantitative variables.  Here we have two categorical variables – education level and where we work.  If there is a relationship, we say there is an association.  

Return on Friday when we reveal the free link to the article that included this graph.  There you will find graphs that display the association between where workers work and other factors, including race & ethnicity, age and gender and children.  The article gives reasons for the distribution of workers for each of these factors.

name: Ricardo Castillo
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
I noticed that as the level of education increases, more people seem to be learning virtually or through hybrid models. For example, bachelor’s degrees have a mix of virtual and in-person learning, while high school or less is mostly in-person. 

2. What do you wonder?
I wonder why higher levels of education have more virtual or hybrid learning options, while lower levels, like high school, are mostly in-person. Is it because the curriculum for higher education is more adaptable to online formats, or are there other factors at play? I’m also curious about how many people this data is based on and how accurate it is in reflecting broader trends.

3. How does this relate to you and your community?
In my community, there’s been a shift toward more virtual learning after COVID-19, especially in higher education. I see that trend reflected in the graph, where virtual learning is more common for bachelor’s degrees and beyond. Personally, my mom, who has the highest level of education, attends in-person classes, which aligns with the fact that more people with advanced degrees still prefer in-person learning, even though hybrid options exist.

4. Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
“Post-Pandemic Shift: Virtual Learning Dominates Higher Education, While Blue-Collar Jobs Keep it In-Person”

name: Ariel
comment info: * What stood out to me is that independent of degree, in person workers dominate the workforce. However what stood out to me, is that those with a bachelors degree work more hybrid numerically, but proportionally those with a graduate degree have more hybrid workers and less workers overall. This stands out to me because those with the highest level degree are those that work the least overall. This is interesting because it would be expected to be the opposite, but can be explained by those working blue collar jobs having to work multiple different professions and shifts since they make less on average, than those that already reached a certain level of success and are able to make the most of their leisurely time as well. This graph sparks curiosities about the number of workers that are undocumented and thus not represented in the graph since they are not counted as part of the U.S Census Bureau. I wonder how this would cause the graphs shape to change its skew or if it would remain relatively them same. This graph can be related to my life and community since I am at such a pivotal time in life for education in choosing a university, as well as now having to factor in technologies role in the future. This graph can be summarized with the headline, ‘Is work worth it?: an evaluate of different degrees leading in type of workers.

That’s a GREAT wonder – “We wonder what this graph would have looked like before the pandemic.”  And, note the date on data.  What would the graph look like now.  Even in today’s New York Times, there was an article about employers requiring workers to return to in person.

comment info:
I notice that most high school graduates work in person, while those with higher education are more likely to work online.

I wonder why an online occupation is more likely for someone with bachelors compared to a graduate degree.

Society is adjusting to being more remote, but many people still can't afford to work remotely or their job position doesn't allow it.

Catchy Headline: After COVID, the work force has adjusted in favor of Bachelors degrees. Here's how.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Lillian Cribari and Juliet O'Connor --

“I wonder why an online occupation is more likely for someone with bachelors compared to a graduate degree.”  Are you comparing number of workers or percentage of workers?  What is the comparison if you use percentage?  

Why is there a difference in your answer using number or percentage?  Which is the appropriate way to compare the educational levels?

name: autumn robison
comment info:
What do you notice?
There is little to no fluctuation among those with a high school or lower level of education. The majority of this population working fully in person. 
What do you wonder?
Why there's more fluctuation with a Bachelor's degree than with a Graduate. Or is it more in a Graduate because of the smaller amount of people?

How does this relate to you and your community?
People with High school education work in person more because their jobs tend to be less technical and have to be done on the site, like cooking food or working service.
Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
"You can't flip burgers online."

name: Renee
comment info: We wondered why during the pandemic many people worked remotely and now why are less people working remotely. We also wondered why less people with Graduate degrees worked less remotely and in Hybrid than people with Bachelor's degrees.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Renee --

Regarding your first wonder, from this graph, can you compare the number of workers in person, hybrid or fully remote during the pandemic vs. where they work now?  

Let’s see if we can tease out the story in this graph.  How many variables are there in this graph?  What are they?  What does this graph compare?  Now, share with us what you notice and what you wonder.

name: Tannin Grant
comment info:
People still working 
Even while still having the pandemic people still had to work and make money, i noticed that people with high school or less worked more in person, people with collage worked a lot in person and a few being remote, bachelors where in person, hybrid, and remote depending on what they did, graduate had a lot smaller total amount of people that worked and they where also hybrid, remote, and in person. This makes me wounder why people did or didnt want to work in person weather they where inside or outside. This relates to our community because it was the same, we had a mix between people working remote, hybrid, and in person.

replies.name: O
replies.comment info:
@Tannin Grant 
Hi, mentioning the benefits of working remotely: you don't need to get up that early, get to and back from work in the traffic, and have a more flexible schedule, which in my opinion is quite a lot of benefits. Still, I would say that only a few jobs offer that flexibility, most still require to work at least sometimes at the location. I believe that there would be some increase in remote jobs however very slow and small compared to the total number of positions.

name: Peyton
comment info:
I notice that the fully remote and hybrid jobs raise the closer you get to a bachelor degree. I wonder why remote working drops once you get a graduate degree. This is important to me because it helps inform me on what career routs i would be interested in looking at.
Remote working raises?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Peyton --

Why do you think that workers with more education tend to work remotely?  Think about the kind of jobs workers with more education tend to have vs. workers with lee education tend to have.
